Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of respiratory failure, pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, and a complicated hospital course. He presented with an episode of respiratory distress yesterday that was resolved with Seroquel. The patient has no known drug allergies. 

In terms of medical history, the patient has the following medications: glargine/SSI, zonpenex, norvasc, thiamine, prevacid, asa, atrovent, lisinopril, prednisone 30 qd, and seroquel. There are no changes to the patient's medical and family history or review of systems except where noted above.

According to the flow sheet data, the patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature range of 37.2 to 35.7 degrees Celsius, heart rate between 109 and 87 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 144/77 to 98/56 mmHg, respiratory rate between 25 and 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 95%. The patient's rhythm is sinus tachycardia.

The patient's weight has decreased from 79.4 kg at admission to 68.6 kg currently. Fluid balance shows an input of 3,352 mL and output of 1,690 mL via IV fluids, with a total output of 2,185 mL including blood products. The patient's urine output is 745 mL.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   # Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Last night he had one such
   episode that resolved with 2 PRN doses of 50mg of Seoquel and 1 dose of
   1mg of Ativan.  This morning he was not moving air well but that is
   likely due to the fact that he was due to have a nebulizer treatment.
   Previous episodes have demonstratred normal ABGs.
   -Considering Seroquel dose was lowered two days ago and prns were
   needed, will increase am and qhs seroquel doses t o150mg and f/u
   w/psych recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 30mg PO qday then 20 mg
   qday starting [**1-8**]
   .
   # Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased am and qhs doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive with
   unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    Vanco dose has been increased, will recheck level.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -appreciate ID input
   -will replace picc with one in other arm
   -if additional BCx come back positive, would favor treating through
   [**Last Name **] problem of poor venous access\
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Lisinopril 10mg PO qday, Amlodipine 5mg PO qday
   - BP has been relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril, can decrease to 5mg
   Lisinopril PO.
   - use Seroquel for hypertension associated with episodes of agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   ..
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN:  failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**]; Dubhoff placed
   [**1-5**]; Passed swallow eval on [**1-6**]: start with ground solids (due to
   lack of teeth) and thin liquids, 1:1 with foods to watch for aspiration
   and CXR on [**1-8**].  Cont. TF for now until patient can take adequate POs
   and it is clear that the patient is not aspirating.  CXR today was
   normal
   -f/u CXR tomorrow.
   .
   #Medical decision making: Given the patient's inability to communicate
   his own wishes, his son is currently pursuing guardianship. call
   [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 3793**] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] 7-1888 on friday. attorney @[**Hospital1 **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]  .
   .
   #PPX: heparin sc, PPI, bowel regimen.
   .
   #Dispo: Appropriate for rehab. Screening in progress.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of COPD, EtOH abuse, and other medical conditions.
- He was admitted with shortness of breath and later experienced a seizure, followed by a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest.
- The patient had a hospital course complicated by pneumothorax (PTX) treated with chest tubes, altered mental status (AMS), agitation, respiratory distress, and coag-negative staph bacteremia.
- He has been transferred back to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) from the floor due to ongoing episodes of dyspnea and respiratory distress.
- The patient is currently on various medications including vancomycin, steroids, atenolol, lisinopril, amlodipine, and seroquel.
- His vital signs include a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, blood pressure of 83/57 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%.
- The patient's physical examination reveals poor air movement bilaterally, and he is not arousable but moves all four extremities to irritating stimuli.

   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   # Dyspnea / COPD exacerbation:  He has been improving since IV steroid
   course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone taper,
   though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing,
   belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually occur at
   night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and resolve
   with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU from the
   floor for similar episodes.  This morning he was moving more air in his
   lungs than usual and stated that he was comfortable.  Previous episodes
   have demonstratred normal ABGs.
   -cont. lower dose of seroquel 100 mg TID  b/c of episode of somnolence
   on [**1-4**].
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 30mg PO qday then 20 mg
   qday starting [**1-8**]
   .
   # Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive with
   unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    Vanco dose has been increased, will recheck level.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   - would favor treating through [**Last Name **] problem of poor venous access
   - appreciate ID input
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.
   - on Lisinopril 10mg PO qday, Amlodipine 5mg PO qday: follow BP, if too
   low w/10 of lisinopril, consider decreasing dose (not 1:1dosing with
   captopril).
   - use seroquel for hypertension associated with episodes of agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin

   distress
   - continue telemetry
    .

   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.

Based on the provided information, the patient is a 64-year-old man with severe COPD who was admitted with an exacerbation and complicated by a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. The patient has been in the ICU for an extended period of time and has required multiple interventions and medications.

The patient experienced an episode of respiratory distress last night and required multiple doses of Seroquel to reduce agitation. He is currently sedated and responsive only to pain. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.2 C, heart rate of 101 bpm, blood pressure of 86/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count within normal range, slightly elevated creatinine level, and normal glucose levels. Other lab values are within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination reveals diminished pulses in both lower extremities and clear breath sounds bilaterally. The patient has muscle wasting and is unable to stand. Neurological examination is limited due to sedation.

The patient's medical history includes COPD, hypertension, and ethanol abuse. He is currently on lisinopril for hypertension, but it is being held due to low blood pressure. The patient is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include respiratory failure due to exacerbation

   Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.  BP was relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril,
   decreased to 5mg Lisinopril PO and BPs have been stable.
   - use Seroquel PRN for hypertension associated with episodes of
   agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a complicated medical history, including COPD, EtOH abuse, who was admitted with shortness of breath and later experienced a seizure, cardiac arrest, and subsequent hospital course complicated by pneumonia, acute mental status changes, respiratory distress, and coag-negative staph bacteremia.

The patient's current medical issues include dyspnea/respiratory distress, altered mental status/bipolar disorder, coag-negative staph bacteremia, hypertension, abnormal neuro exam, s/p cardiac arrest, ETOH abuse, history of alcoholic hepatitis, and failed speech and swallow evaluation.

Treatment and management plans include increasing the doses of seroquel for agitation, continuing xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers, slow prednisone taper, vancomycin for coag-negative staph bacteremia, monitoring mental status and neuro exam, considering restarting beta-blocker, continuing folate, thiamine, and MVI, starting with ground solids and thin liquids due to failed speech and swallow evaluation, and pursuing guardianship for medical decision-making.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory distress, persistent encephalopathy, recurrent bacteremia, uncontrolled hypertension, further neurologic deterioration, and potential aspiration due to failed speech and swallow evaluation.

Please note that this summary is based on the information provided in the progress note.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient has been improving on an IV steroid course, but continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis at night. These episodes resolve with nebs and seroquel.
- His mental status has improved with treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation.
- He has positive cultures for coag-negative staph bacteremia, with unclear source. Extensive workup has been done, including TTE, LENIs, and MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess. The patient would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE without re-intubation.
- His blood pressure improved on the current regimen, but he becomes hypertensive during episodes of agitation, which resolves with seroquel. His current medications include Lisinopril 10mg PO qday and Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.
- His neuro exam has improved with treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation.
- He had a cardiac arrest with unknown cause, possibly related to a seizure. He underwent cooling protocol and his head CT after

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   #1 Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Last night he had one such
   episode that resolved with 2 PRN doses of 50mg of Seoquel and 1 dose of
   1mg of Ativan.  This morning and last he was not moving air well but
   that is likely due to the fact that he was due to have a nebulizer
   treatment.  Previous episodes have demonstratred normal ABGs.
   -Considering Seroquel dose was lowered three days ago and although
   increased yesterday prns were needed, will increase doses to
   200/150/200 w/25mg PRNs (with total of 800mg daily MAX) and f/u w/psych
   recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 30mg PO qday then 20 mg
   qday starting [**1-8**]
   .
   #2 Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #3 Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive
   with unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    Vanco dose has been increased, will recheck level.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 6-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -appreciate ID input
   -will replace picc with one in other arm tomorrow (in IR) if BCx from
   [**1-4**] still pending or turns positive
   -if additional BCx come back positive after PICC replaced, team would
   favor treating through [**Last Name **] problem of poor venous access
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.  BP was relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril,
   decreased to 5mg Lisinopril PO and BPs have been stable.
   - use Seroquel PRN for hypertension associated with episodes of
   agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   .
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN:  failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**]; Dubhoff placed
   [**1-5**]; Passed swallow eval on [**1-6**]: start with ground solids (due to
   lack of teeth) and thin liquids, 1:1 with foods to watch for aspiration
   and CXR on [**1-8**].  Cont. TF for now until patient can take adequate POs
   and it is clear that the patient is not aspirating.  CXR today was
   normal
   -f/u CXR tomorrow.
   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 64-year-old male with a complicated medical history including COPD, EtOH abuse, who was admitted with shortness of breath and later experienced a seizure, PEA arrest, and subsequent hospital course complicated by pneumothorax, acute mental status changes, respiratory distress, and coag-negative staph bacteremia.
- The patient has been experiencing episodes of respiratory distress, characterized by tachypnea, wheezing, and diaphoresis, which usually occur at night and resolve with nebs and seroquel.
- His mental status has been fluctuating, with periods of agitation and confusion, likely due to underlying psychiatric conditions and superimposed delirium.
- The patient had a positive blood culture for coag-negative staph bacteremia, but the source of infection is unclear. He has undergone extensive workup including TTE, LENIs, and MRI of the head and C-spine, which did not reveal any abscesses.
- His blood pressure has been relatively stable on the current regimen, although he becomes hypertensive during episodes of agitation.
- The patient's neuro exam has shown abnormalities, but imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for persistent encephalopathy. However, with treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation, his mental status has begun to improve.
- The patient is scheduled for a swallow evaluation and has been placed on a Dubhoff tube due to failed speech and swallow evaluation.

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, acute on chronic. He has a history of hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), anxiety, and anemia secondary to blood loss. Seroquel is now dosed at 200/150/200 with 25-50mg Q6h, with a max 24h total seroquel dose of 800mg. The patient's PICC line was pulled back.    Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M transferred back to the MICU with complicated PMH including
   COPD, EtOH abuse admitted with SOB, left AMA and had a seizure in
   lobby, with PEA arrest with subsequent hospital course complicated by
   PTX s/p chest tubes, AMS/agitation, respiratory distress and coag
   negative staph bacteremia.
   .
   #1 Dyspnea / Respiratory Distress:  He had been improving throughout IV
   steroid course and now with stable respiratory status on prednisone
   taper, though he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea,
   wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.  These episodes usually
   occur at night when he is awakened by nursing for bed turns or labs and
   resolve with nebs and seroquel.  He was transferred back to the ICU
   from the floor for similar episodes.  Previous episodes have
   demonstratred normal ABGs.  Decreased respiratory distress overnight on
   new, increased standing dose of seroquel
   -Cont. trial of Seroquel 200/150/200 w/25mg PRNs (with total of 800mg
   daily MAX) and f/u w/psych recommendations RE treating agitation.
   -continue xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   -continue slow prednisone taper with Prednisone 20 mg qday (then 10 mg
   qd x 3 days, then 5 mg
   .
   #2 Altered Mental Status/Bipolar disorder:  Reason Most likely due to
   underlying psychiatric diagnosis, bipolar vs schizoaffective disorder,
   as well as superimposed delirium [**3-15**] long ICU
   stay/bacteremia/intubation/IV steroids.  He had MRI brain without
   evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes to explain
   encephalopathy that was performed a couple of weeks after his cardiac
   arrest.  Due to this interval time period, the team does not feel that
   a second MRI would be beneficial or suggest alternative causes for
   continued AMS.  Additionally, patient would need to be re-intubated for
   MRI.
   -          continue seroquel  at increased doses.
   -          appreciate psych input
   .
   #3 Coag negative staph Bacteremia:  New cultures from [**1-2**] positive
   with unclear source.  Has had extensive workup in the past with TTE X 2
   (most recent [**12-29**]), LENIs with imaging of femoral arteries to assess
   for aneurysm, MRI of head and C-spine without evidence of abscess.  Pt
   would not tolerate repeat MRI or TEE at this point without
   re-intubation.    No further cultures have come back positive, so [**1-2**] be a contaminate.
   -continue vancomycin to complete a 2-week course after last positive
   blood culture
   -will keep PICC line in for now as patient has poor access.
   .
   # Hypertension: prior to this admission was on lisinopril and atenolol,
   blood pressure improved on current regimen although he does become very
   hypertensive w/agitated episodes, which resolves w/seroquel.  On
   Amlodipine 5mg PO qday.  BP was relatively low w/10mg of Lisinopril,
   decreased to 5mg Lisinopril PO and BPs have been stable.
   - use Seroquel PRN for hypertension associated with episodes of
   agitation.
   .
   # Abnormal neuro exam: Imaging and EEG have shown no explanation for
   persistent encephalopathy and abnormal reflexes. However, with
   treatment for bacteremia and seroquel for agitation with improvement in
   mental status, the patient's neuro exam has begun to improve. Of note,
   he did have an EMG that was concerning for polyneuropathy. B12 was
   normal.
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - monitor mental status and neuro exam
   . .
   # s/p cardiac arrest: Cause unknown, a seizure may have been a
   component of the initial picture given his unresponsiveness, abnormal
   movements, and incontinence. Per his family, he has had cardiac arrests
   in the past. He is now s/p paralysis and sedation for the cardiac
   arrest cooling protocol. He was started on an amiodarone gtt which has
   since been d/c'd. He had a head CT after he was rewarmed that was
   unremarkable.
   - continue aspirin
   - beta blocker is being held due to COPD exacerbation and respiratory
   distress. To consider re-starting today or tomorrow if patient is
   tachycardic/if bp allows.
   .
   # ETOH abuse: unknown history of withdrawal seizures or DTs. Arrest may
   have been due to withdrawal seizure given timing to serum etoh levels
   on day of event.   Has been off benzo
s now for a few weeks.
   -continue folate, thiamine, MVI
   .
   # History of alcoholic hepatitis: No LFTs in many years, but normal on
   check [**2104-12-4**].
   .
   # FEN:  failed a speech and swallow evaluation on [**12-31**]; Dubhoff placed
   [**1-5**]; Passed swallow eval on [**1-6**]: start with ground solids (due to
   lack of teeth) and thin liquids, 1:1 with foods to watch for aspiration
   and CXR on [**1-8**].  Cont. TF for now until patient can take adequate
   POs.  Patient is unable to eat by himself as he lacks the motor
   coordination to do so.
   Would like to avoid PEG tube placement as patient would likely not have
   wanted that and given his respiratory status may require intubation for
   PEG placement.
   .
   #Medical decision making: Given the patient's inability to communicate
   his own wishes, his son is currently pursuing guardianship. call
   [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 3793**] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] 7-1888 on friday. attorney @[**Hospital1 **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]  .
   .
   #PPX: heparin sc, PPI, bowel regimen.
   .
   #Dispo: Appropriate for rehab. Screening in progress.

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a complicated medical history including COPD, EtOH abuse, and previous hospitalizations. He was admitted with shortness of breath, left AMA, and experienced a seizure in the lobby followed by a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. The patient has had a hospital course complicated by pneumothorax (PTX) after chest tubes, altered mental status (AMS), respiratory distress, and coag-negative staph bacteremia. The patient's current condition is stable with controlled respiratory status on prednisone taper, but he continues to have daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Dyspnea/Respiratory Distress: The patient's episodes of respiratory distress may recur, particularly at night when he is awakened for nursing interventions or lab draws. Monitoring his response to nebs and seroquel will be important.

2. Altered Mental Status/Bipolar Disorder: The patient's AMS may persist due to underlying psychiatric diagnosis or superimposed delirium. Continued use of increased doses of seroquel and psych input are recommended.

3. Coag-negative Staph Bacteremia: The source of the bacteremia is unclear, and the patient has had extensive workup without evidence of abscess. Completion of a 2-week course of vancomycin is planned.

4. Hypertension: The patient's

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who has been admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure. He has had a prolonged ICU course complicated by recurrent bacteremia, altered mental status, and respiratory failure. The patient has shown stability post-extubation but continues to have a slow improvement in mental status.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is being weaned off oxygen as tolerated, continuing with inhaled bronchodilators, and ambulating as tolerated.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is being managed with Seroquel at an increased evening dosage of 200mg qpm and PRN use during the day. Thiamine is also being administered, and psychiatry input is essential due to underlying bipolar disorder.
3. Sepsis/Bacteremia: Vancomycin is being continued for a two-week course for bacteremia following negative cultures.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Anemia, acute secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding)
2. Altered mental status (not delirium)
3. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS/Doctor's Last Name)
4. Cardiac arrest
5. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation
6. Alteration in nutrition
7. Electrolyte & fluid disorder, other
8. Anxiety
9. Hypertension, benign

ICU Care:
The patient's nutrition is being provided through Fibersource HN (Full) at 80 mL/hour. Glycemic control is being maintained using regular insulin sliding scale. Prophylactic measures include DVT prevention with subcutaneous UF heparin and stress ulcer prevention with PPI. The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is currently in the ICU.

Summary: The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of COPD, EtOH abuse, and previous hospital course complicated by PTX, AMS, respiratory distress, and coag-negative staph bacteremia. He was admitted with shortness of breath and subsequently experienced a seizure followed by PEA arrest. After resuscitation, he was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. He had a prolonged ICU stay and developed ventilator-associated pneumonia, which was treated with IV steroids and antibiotics. He also had episodes of anxiety and agitation, for which he was given seroquel. The patient's respiratory status has improved on prednisone taper, but he still experiences daily episodes of tachypnea, wheezing, belly breathing, and diaphoresis. These episodes occur mainly at night and resolve with nebs and seroquel. He was transferred back to the ICU from the floor for similar episodes. The patient's altered mental status is likely due to an underlying psychiatric diagnosis, such as bipolar disorder or schizoaffective disorder, as well as superimposed delirium caused by long ICU stay, bacteremia, intubation, and IV steroids. An MRI brain showed no evidence of anoxic brain injury or other causes for encephalopathy. The patient also has a history of alcoholic hepatitis and EtOH abuse. He is currently being treated for coag-negative staph bacteremia and has completed a 2-week course of vancomycin. His blood
